section: Section 2 – Codes and Amateur Radio Abbreviations. Rules and Procedures for Amateur Radio Contacts

questions.question_body: Which amateur radio abbreviation is used to transmit "end of message"?
Which amateur radio abbreviation is used to transmit "near" or "close to"?
How will you inform the correspondent in an amateur radio contest to "send the contact serial number again"?
What is the meaning of the abbreviation "ABT"?
What is the meaning of the code "QRQ"?
What is the meaning of the code "QRP"?

choices.text: Transmitter with extremely low power (up to 5 W)

questions.question_body: What will you do if during a radio contact on telegraphy (CW), you hear the code "QRS" from the correspondent?

choices.text: You will remain listening until the correspondent calls again

questions.question_body: What is the meaning of the abbreviation "RPT AA"?
Which abbreviation means "wait a moment"?
What is the meaning of the code "QRU"?

choices.text: I have a message for you

questions.question_body: What is the meaning of the code "QRX"?

choices.text: Your keying is difficult to understand

questions.question_body: If you hear the distant station transmit the code "QRZ?", what will you do?

choices.text: You will wait some time, the distant operator is busy
You will transmit your call sign
You will move to another frequency

questions.question_body: What is the meaning of the code "QRT"?

choices.text: I have nothing more for you
Turn off (I am turning off) the radio station

questions.question_body: What is the meaning of the abbreviation "BK"?

choices.text: I have a message for you

questions.question_body: What is the meaning of the abbreviation "CALL"?
What is the meaning of the code "QSB"?
What is the meaning of the code "QSY"?
What is the meaning of the abbreviation "SKED"?
What is the meaning of the abbreviation "PA"?
What is the meaning of the abbreviation "FM"?
Can you use any of the listed abbreviations to communicate "start transmitting"?
What does the abbreviation "MNY" mean?
What does the abbreviation "OM" mean?
What does the abbreviation "TX" mean?
What does the abbreviation "RPT" mean?
Which of the listed abbreviations means "short waves"?
What is the meaning of the abbreviation "RX"?
What does the abbreviation "LID" mean?

choices.text: I have nothing more for you

questions.question_body: Which amateur radio code is equivalent to the abbreviation "CL"?
What is the meaning of the abbreviation "CQ TEST"?

choices.text: General call to radio stations participating in an amateur radio contest
General call for performing a technical test

questions.question_body: How will you ask your correspondent to send you a QSL card in a shortwave amateur radio contest?

choices.text: With the abbreviations "PSE YOUR QSL CARD TO MY ADDRESS OR VIA LZ QSL BUREAU"
With the abbreviations "PSE YOUR QSL VIA BURO = MY QSL IS SURE = TNX"
You will not request a QSL card from the correspondent, because it is not accepted that radio contacts during contests are confirmed with QSL cards
You will not specifically request a QSL card from the correspondent, so as not to interfere with their participation in the contest

questions.question_body: Which of the listed abbreviations is usually used at the beginning of a radio contact, immediately after the call signs?
Which of the messages is incorrectly composed?
Which two amateur radio call signs are from countries in North America?
Which three call signs are from countries in Europe?
Which two call signs are NOT from countries in Europe?
Which two call signs are NOT from countries in Europe?
Which two call signs are NOT from countries in Europe?
From which continent is the amateur radio operator with call sign OA5HK transmitting?
From which continent is the amateur radio operator with call sign 9A2AC transmitting?
Which amateur radio operator is transmitting from the territory of New Zealand?
Which of the following amateur radio operators is located closest to Bulgaria?
Which of the following amateur radio operators is located farthest from Bulgaria?
Which of the following American amateur radio operators is located closest to Bulgaria?
Which of the following American amateur radio operators is located farthest from Bulgaria?
What is the amateur radio organization of Russia?
What is the amateur radio organization of Romania?
What is the amateur radio organization of the Netherlands?
ARI is the amateur radio organization of?
Which regions of the world are included in Region 1 of ITU (and correspondingly IARU)?

choices.text: Europe, Africa, the Middle East and Northern Asia

questions.question_body: Into how many amateur radio zones is the world divided according to the ITU distribution?
In which amateur radio zone according to the ITU distribution does the territory of Bulgaria fall?
Into how many amateur radio zones is the world divided according to the CQ/DXCC distribution?
In which amateur radio zone according to the CQ/DXCC distribution does the territory of Bulgaria fall?
Approximately how many countries and territories according to DXCC exist in the world?
Which bands count for the amateur radio diploma 6B DXCC?

choices.text: 1.8 MHz, 3.5 MHz, 7 MHz, 14 MHz, 21 MHz, 28 MHz
3.5 MHz, 7 MHz, 14 MHz, 21 MHz, 28 MHz, 50 MHz
7 MHz, 10 MHz, 14 MHz, 18 MHz, 21 MHz, 24 MHz

questions.question_body: Which of the following amateur radio operators is it correct to answer if this operator has made a CQ DX call on the 14 MHz band?
Which of the following amateur radio operators is it correct to answer if this operator has made a CQ DX call on the 10 MHz band?
If you are participating in the ARRL contest, approximately at what azimuth should you point your antenna?
If you are participating in the JARL contest, approximately at what azimuth should you point your antenna?
Which of the listed messages is mandatory to exchange between amateur radio operators in international amateur radio contests?
Should QSL cards be sent to confirm a radio contact made during an amateur radio contest?

choices.text: No, if a contest report has been sent
No, because radio contacts during contests are not recognized for any amateur radio awards
Yes, but only if the correspondent has requested it

questions.question_body: Which three elements represent part of the information mandatory for entry on every QSL card?

choices.text: Correspondent's name, date of radio contact, emission class
Time of radio contact, correspondent's call sign, band
Date of radio contact, emission class, correspondent's address

questions.question_body: What is the DXCC amateur radio award issued for?

choices.text: For confirmed radio contacts with amateur radio operators from all continents
For confirmed radio contacts with amateur radio operators from all amateur radio zones
For confirmed radio contacts with amateur radio operators from 100 countries
For a prize place (from first to third) in the contest with the same name

questions.question_body: On which shortwave amateur radio band, if any, is telephony operation not permitted?

choices.text: Telephony is permitted on all three bands

questions.question_body: If a Bulgarian amateur radio operator is operating with emission class A1A, on which shortwave amateur radio band will they not be able to establish a simplex radio contact with an amateur radio operator from the second or third ITU region (and correspondingly IARU) due to differences in band allocations in the three regions?

choices.text: Such a problem does not exist, the bands for emission class A1A coincide in the three regions

questions.question_body: If a Bulgarian amateur radio operator is operating on SSB, on which shortwave amateur radio band will they not be able to establish a simplex radio contact with an amateur radio operator from the USA and Canada due to differences in band allocations in ITU region 2 (and correspondingly IARU)?

choices.text: Such a problem does not exist on the mentioned bands, the SSB bands coincide

questions.question_body: If a Bulgarian amateur radio operator is operating with emission class J3E, on which shortwave amateur radio band will they not be able to establish a simplex radio contact with an amateur radio operator from Japan due to differences in band allocations in ITU region 3 (and correspondingly IARU)?

choices.text: Such a problem does not exist on the mentioned bands, the bands for emission class J3E coincide

questions.question_body: On what frequency does a Bulgarian amateur radio operator have the right and should transmit to establish a radio contact on SSB with W9 on the 7 MHz band?
On what frequency should a Bulgarian amateur radio operator receive to establish a radio contact on SSB with W9 on the 7 MHz band?
What is packet radio?

choices.text: Compression of telegraph signal to increase speed during radio contact via meteor scatter
Connecting several radio stations operating on RTTY in a common network
Radio contact established between amateur radio operators using computers
Computer program for checking and reporting amateur radio contests

questions.question_body: What advantages does packet radio contact have over CW radio contact?

choices.text: Packet radio contact uses a narrower frequency band and is therefore less vulnerable to interference
Packet radio contact is automatic and does not require operator presence
DX radio contacts are easier to establish on packet than on CW
Information exchanged during the radio contact is stored more completely and more easily

questions.question_body: At what modulation level should an amateur radio repeater transmit its identification call sign?

choices.text: Level sufficient to block the repeated signal
Level low enough not to cause interference in the repeated signal
Level sufficient for identification during signal retransmission
The level specified in the Technical Requirements for Electronic Communications through Amateur Radio Service Equipment

questions.question_body: How will you recognize that the amateur repeater through which you have established a radio contact is located outside Bulgaria?

choices.text: By the language that is most often spoken
By the coordinates transmitted by the repeater
By the directionality of your antenna

questions.question_body: What is an amateur transponder?

choices.text: The suppressed carrier frequency of an SSB signal
An amateur repeater mounted on an Earth satellite that retransmits from one continent to another
An amateur repeater mounted on an Earth satellite that retransmits a given frequency band from one amateur radio band to another
The effect by which the satellite signal frequency shifts depending on whether the satellite is approaching or moving away from the amateur radio operator's location

questions.question_body: What is BBS?

choices.text: Broad Band System for improving intelligibility in SSB radio contacts
The amateur radio organization of Belgium
Electronic mailbox used in packet communications
The national radio station of Great Britain

questions.question_body: When is it permissible to interrupt a QSO being conducted between amateur radio operators with the word "Break"?

choices.text: Whenever you wish to conduct a QSO
Only if you start your report with "Break, break"
Only if you start your report with "Break, break, break"

Only when your or someone else's life is in imminent danger or in distress or emergency situations, when the information you have is vital and needs to be transmitted to third parties participating in the emergency traffic

questions.question_body: On which amateur radio bands are amateur radio contests most often conducted?

choices.text: 1.8 MHz, 3.5 MHz, 7 MHz, 14 MHz, 21 MHz, 28 MHz
3.5 MHz, 7 MHz, 10 MHz, 14 MHz, 18 MHz, 21 MHz
1.8 MHz, 3.5 MHz, 10 MHz, 18 MHz, 24 MHz, 28 MHz
10 MHz, 18 MHz, 21 MHz, 24 MHz, 28 MHz, 50 MHz

questions.question_body: Is it permissible during an amateur radio contest to ask your correspondent to send you a QSL card?

choices.text: Yes, but if you also send them one
If this is a new entity for you, it is permissible
Yes, but only if you are the station calling CQ CONTEST

questions.question_body: Which of the following is NOT acceptable to do on the frequency of a DX station while it is conducting radio contacts?

choices.text: Start calling them before they have finished their QSO with the correspondent
When the DX station announces that it is waiting for the next correspondent, start repeating your call sign multiple times expecting them to answer you
Tune your transmitter on the operating frequency of the DX station

questions.question_body: What behavior should you have during a contest when a station on an adjacent frequency starts interfering with your clear reception of your correspondents' signals?

choices.text: You should increase the power you are operating with to drive away the intruder
Widen the bandwidth you are transmitting with to interfere with them too
Move to their frequency and start operating on their signal
Narrow the filter of your receiver as much as possible and if this does not help, ask the adjacent station to move a few kilohertz

questions.question_body: Is it necessary and if so, why, to listen to the frequency for several minutes before you start transmitting on it?

choices.text: If you don't hear anything, it means the frequency is free
It is necessary to listen for a few minutes because you may interrupt a QSO
It is sufficient to ask once if the frequency is free and if no one answers you, start transmitting on it

questions.question_body: Which of the following is unacceptable when conducting radio contacts on short waves?

choices.text: Transmitting only a few letters/digits of your call sign to make it more attractive to the calling station
Transmitting your call sign or part of it on top of a weaker or QRP station's signal
Tuning your transmitter on top of the calling station's signal

questions.question_body: Which of the following is acceptable when conducting radio contacts on short waves?

choices.text: When you have established contact with a very "rare" station, to repeat the contact with your friend's call sign if he has given you permission to do so
When you have established contact with a very "rare" station, to ask them to accept a contact with your friend who is also calling them
During a contest to ask the station you are in contact with to mark you in the DX cluster (Spot)
To ask the DX station to conduct contacts only with your country

questions.question_body: Is self-spotting in DX clusters permitted during contests?

choices.text: Yes, because this way we show other stations where to find us
It is permitted only in domestic contests

questions.question_body: Is it permitted to announce the call sign of a "rare" station in the DX cluster and indicate the frequency on which you are transmitting in order to gather more contacts?

choices.text: It is permitted, but only during international contests
It is neither permitted nor prohibited, but it is unethical toward other amateur radio operators

questions.question_body: Which of the listed shortwave contests is declared to be the most prestigious and most difficult in amateur radio?
Is it normal under ordinary conditions to use CQ DX on frequency 14.300 MHz?

choices.text: No, this is an emergency frequency designated for IARU Region 1 and should remain clear
As long as there is no declared emergency situation, it is permitted
Yes, IARU Region 1 has other emergency frequencies
Yes, the frequency is within the limits of the 20 meter band

questions.question_body: In a declared disaster situation, you have information that must be transmitted on the air. What is the most correct action?

choices.text: You find where on the air there is the greatest concentration of operators and transmit the information there
You start sequential transmission on all frequencies known to you
You start continuous radio transmission on the band where you transmit best

Taking into account at what distance you need to transmit the information, you select the appropriate band, find the emergency communication frequency designated by IARU Region 1, announce yourself to the Net Control operating there, and wait to be called to communicate your information

questions.question_body: What are the frequencies designated for emergency communications by IARU Region 1?
What is a distress signal?

choices.text: A distress signal is the code SOS transmitted on telegraph
A distress signal is the word MAYDAY transmitted on telephony
Answers A and B are correct

A distress signal is an internationally accepted way of requesting help when human lives are in immediate and inevitable danger, with signaling performed via radio communication, visual or acoustic means

questions.question_body: Which answer contains entirely elements from the "Amateur Radio Code"?

choices.text: The amateur radio operator is: courteous, loyal, progressive, friendly, balanced, patriotic
The amateur radio operator is: smart, good, technician, engineer, electrical engineer
The amateur radio operator is: resourceful, intelligent, self-confident, good technician
The amateur radio operator is: loud-voiced, with very good hearing, excellent knowledge of electrical engineering
